Expenses paid for volunteers during McConnell tour

McConnell campaign manager says "standard practice" for volunteers, but Democrats say paid-to-cheer

Expenses paid for volunteers during McConnell tour

Politics

Tom Loftus, The Courier-Journal 8:03 p.m. EDT October 22, 2014
Buy Photo

Sen. Mitch McConnell campaigns in Eastern Kentucky in Ashland, Ky. Wednesday, October 22, 2014. (Photo: By Mike Weaver, Special to the CJ)Buy Photo

Tags

  • Democratic Party
  • Josh Holmes
22 CONNECT 20 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

Volunteers who went on Sen. Mitch McConnell's three-day campaign bus tour this week had their hotel rooms and other expenses paid, prompting supporters of Democrat Alison Lundergan Grimes to question the enthusiasm for McConnell at the grassroots level.

But Josh Holmes, chairman of the McConnell re-election campaign, said the volunteers worked throughout the tour in Eastern Kentucky, and paying expenses for such volunteers is "standard practice" in major political campaigns.

The Hill first reported this week that an email earlier this month from a Kentucky Republican Party official asked prospective volunteers to join the three day tour. "You would join local supporters in contributing to an enthusiastic atmosphere at each of his (McConnell's) events. The trip is free – meals, transportation, and lodging will be provided," the email said.

RELATED: McConnell in E. Ky., calls Grimes 'status quo'

RELATED: Realtors' ad hangs "For Sale" sign on Mitch McConnell

Daniel Logsdon, chairman of the Kentucky Democratic Party, said that the email doesn't say what volunteers will be expected to do other than to contribute to an enthusiastic atmosphere. "It looks to me they were just asked to show up and cheer. Alison does not have to do that," Logsdon said.

Holmes said a 17-stop, three-day bus tour needs many volunteers – with some setting up one event while the previous one is still underway. He said he did not know how many expense-paid volunteers went on the Eastern Kentucky trip.

"It's not an inordinate number of people," Holmes said. "…And when you bring people along to give them stuff to do, the least you can do is pick up their hotel room."

McConnell received enthusiastic receptions by about 100 people each at the bus trip's first two stops early Wednesday in Ashland and Grayson. Those interviewed by The Courier-Journal were local McConnell supporters - but some campaign staff members and others wearing "Team Mitch" T-shirts attended events in both towns.

Asked at the Grayson stop about the matter and whether he was concerned about the enthusiasm level of his supporters, McConnell said, "We've got a lot of enthusiastic supporters, frankly. And I'm thrilled to have them here."
